Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I was curled up on the couch, phone in hand, about to send my usual weekend text to Mom and Dad: “Hey, just checking in. Hope you’re both well.” It was something small, but I knew it meant a lot to them. Just as I started typing, the building alarms blared, and my phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning. I looked out the window—water was already creeping up the street, and people were shouting in the hallway, urging everyone to help move sandbags and check on neighbors.

My parents always worried about me, especially during emergencies. I knew they’d want to hear from me right away, to know I was safe. But as a member of this community, I felt a responsibility to help, to do my part in keeping everyone safe. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, torn between reassuring my parents and rushing out to help my neighbors. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I hesitated, caught between the pull of family and the call of duty.
